That is not complicated. I know how things work or are complicated. That, in its essence, is not a complicated thing. We have accepted that there is at least a plausible case to be made that a genocide is taking place in Gaza. Nobody should be allowing a weapon near the place.
The clock has gone haywire. It is no longer working. I will bring in Deputy Lahart.

I have a couple of points to make. I do not expect complicity. I say that as just an ordinary member of the committee. I would argue that point with Ms Clancy publicly. We came to hear about the flotilla and I have spoken to Deputy Heneghan about it at length. He was not a witness today, unfortunately, but I heard his story first hand and was quite shaken by the actuality of it. I will follow up by way of a parliamentary question regarding the issues that appear to be outstanding in terms of the role of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade. That is one piece.

I am conscious of the Gallery here. The Taoiseach, as Head of Government, has said the Irish Government's role, duty, responsibility and objective has been - and I am not here to defend the Government - to send a clear message to the Israelis over a long period of time. The Irish Government has done that, sometimes to the point of marginalisation and isolation internationally, and I say that from an educated, knowledgeable point of view. The Government also has a duty to everybody else here in Ireland and that is to make sure we are not punished in the process. Ms Clancy may differ on that piece; I do not. I want the witnesses to know we are on the same side here. I, and other colleagues, some of whom are not here, lead the Irish delegation to the Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe Parliamentary Assembly and I am chair of the Oireachtas Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Trade. Every time we represent this country abroad, we raise this issue with our international partners. We raise it absolutely every time, whether it is a Fianna Fáil TD, a Fine Gael Senator or TD, Independents, members of the Labour Party or of Sinn Féin. Every single one of us does that. We talk about the common themes that draw us into this, such as the famine piece, the oppression piece and the occupation piece. The witnesses may be assured that every one of their representatives does this and represents this country. Sometimes words are not enough but words also ensure that something is continuously kept on the agenda. On the EU-Israel Association Agreement, when we brought it up a few years ago, just one member supported it and then over a matter of time, because momentum had been built up, 18 or 19 eventually supported it. We are also looking at the peace piece at the moment and how Ireland could harness its experience in terms of peace in the North and decommissioning. Our committee will look at that probably in the new year.

I hate that we divide on this. I have had graffiti about me sprayed in my constituency, accusing me of complicity in genocide by people who do not know what I regard as taking a leadership role as Chair of the foreign affairs committee. The committee did not divide on the occupied territories Bill. There was not a vote on it. We all agreed on every measure that was in it. That report also recognises Government has completely different responsibilities from a committee and faces a far greater burden. It has responsibility to business, to the economy and to society and faces much bigger issues than we have had to deal with here.

The witnesses have wanted us to leave with messages. I have been very impacted by the reports they have given us. I thank them for what they did. It was a really courageous, ballsy thing to do and it is what marks us out as individuals. I thank them for doing that. I really want to pay tribute to them.

However, we, in this House, are not their enemies. We fight hard. Words are our weapons and sometimes they are not strong enough. I accept that. Ireland is small. When you go abroad representing the country, you get a real impression, particularly in today's world, of how small it is. However, our voice is big. We are leaving with messages the witnesses have imparted to us. I would like them to leave here knowing that every single opportunity we get we raise this with every single politician, whether in the US, in Canada, as happened recently, or with our international neighbours at European level. We raise it at every possible level.
So, what do you think is preventing it from stopping?
It is not for me to answer that.

It is really important to mention balance, and I know it was mentioned earlier. I have to say really strongly that there is absolutely no place for balance in a genocide. We have call out really strongly that, as much as I appreciate the fact that Deputy Lahart says he calls it out at every step he takes, meaningful action is why we are here today. As much as he says we are part of the EU and there are certain things that have to be agreed through the EU, we are allowing weapons to fly through our airspace. It is being repeated. People here have said that they absolutely stand against it as well. This has been called out for decades but now more than ever. It is the same with the trade agreement. It has been shown now that we have a right to change that because of the human rights violations that are happening. Therefore, there is no place for balance. This is not about trying to make out that anybody here does not care about the oppression of any other person in Ireland or anywhere else. We stand very strongly with anybody who is struggling within Ireland or anywhere else but we are watching a genocide unfold in front of our face, so we cannot use the word "balance" when we are talking about it.

To be clear, certainly in terms of what I said, and I know from discussions at this committee, we are not saying it should be balance in relation to genocide. The balance I am talking about is just acknowledgement of the fact that we have done things. I totally accept Ms Moynihan's opinion that we have not done enough. I may even share aspects of it. Deputy Lahart has mentioned international forums. I go to the Conference of Parliamentary Committees for Union Affairs, COSAC, which is a committee of all the European affairs committees of the European Union. We also raise it there, as do the delegations. The EU-Israel Association Agreement is on the work programme for the Joint Committee on European Affairs. The issues the witnesses raise are very much part of our work programme. Ms Clancy was saying we are the EU. I agree with that statement absolutely but we are also only one of 27 member states. I know, and Deputy Lahart will have shared this, you come up against a brick wall on this issue with certain countries.
Agreed.

We are totally at odds with Germany, for example. I genuinely fear, as a pro European, that the favourable reputation of Europe in Ireland will be damaged by the failure of the European Union to act in relation to this. We cannot act alone, unfortunately.

It is really important at this point to mention that one of the reasons we are all here is because - I will speak for myself but I think everyone else will agree - I do not believe the international institutions are doing what we are asking them to do any longer. That is why the global movement has started. The global movement is the biggest the world has ever seen. There are countries and citizens from every corner of the globe, nationalities from over 80 different countries, who are involved in this global movement right now, and that is only going to grow. It is something we all need to consider. I know we do not want to be divided but we are currently divided. That is why Irish citizens and other people are putting their lives directly at risk and will continue to do so because we do not believe that the speed of what is happening is in any way appropriate to watch over two years of a genocide. There are no excuses left.

By way of closing, I will comment very briefly. I have a statement and I also have a request to ask of the committee in terms of whether we are doing everything we can do. Genocide is the crime of all crimes. It is erga omnes, which in international humanitarian law and international law just means no matter how it happens or where it happens, it is deplorable and all actions must be taken against it to prevent and it. I will let Ms Clancy in for a moment and I will come back.

I know people were cut off earlier and that people in the Gallery wanted to make comments. Unfortunately, we cannot take comments from the Gallery but I do want to give anybody who felt they did not get a chance to finish a point earlier a chance to finish it now.

The end of that thought is that there is something self-negating in Deputy Lahart's point - and I say this respectfully - in that he has made an assertion that he has called it out on every available occasion over the last number of decades. However, if that was effective, then this would not be happening. The Palestinian community has been suffocated in every which way for nearly eight decades now.

It has escalated to a point of absolute devastation. Even if the state is recognised, if they do not have a land to return to or infrastructure where they can live, that recognition of a state is futile. The only thing that we know that works is economic means. Boycott, divest and sanction is the only thing that has turned around deplorable statutory actions and deplorable human rights in apartheid regimes in other settings. That is the only effective means to remedy this. That is why addressing the Joint Oireachtas Committee on Foreign Affairs and Trade is so pivotal. This committee has a large capacity to effect and make a difference to Palestinian lives.

My last question and request is simply that the committee asks the Tánaiste what he meant when he stated that there would be accountability for breaches of international law in the public statement that he cosigned with 15 other nation states and Heads of State on 16 September 2025. I want to know specifically what breaches meant in that context, what breaches he was specifically referring to and what accountability he was specifically referring to.

Deputy Ward had to leave. There are a few housekeeping bits before I come to the next speaker. It seems to be a particularly busy day for Senator Stephenson in the Seanad because she would have definitely have wanted to be here. She texted me that she cannot be here. Deputies Donnchadh Ó Laoghaire and Duncan Smith are from my committee, the foreign affairs committee. An Abitration Bill is going through the House at the moment. They are speaking on that. Otherwise they would have spent more time here. They send their apologies.
I am going to wind up. The witnesses have a minute or two each if they would like to speak to anything.
I am going to address the Comhchathaoirleach directly because I think I hurt his feelings.
Do not think that. I thank her for her consideration.

The people who we are here speaking for are in a lot worse circumstances than any of our feelings. I am speaking to the Comhchathaoirleach for the amputees in Gaza. I am speaking to him for the children with no living relatives who are left. It is not a matter of whether the members are our enemies. They are our representatives. That is all over Ireland. I am a community worker. I work with community groups, the GAA and Tidy Towns. Every person who I am meeting wants more action from the Irish Government on this. This is not an activist. You do not have to be someone going on a flotilla. Everyone the length and breadth of Ireland wants more action.

The reason we want more action specifically is because we are Irish. We know this story. We know the stories of famine and displacement. We know what it takes. We wanted to have our own right to determine our future. We wanted to have the right to elect our government and conduct our own trade. Palestinians only want what we have, what people before us fought for and what all of us defend. The members are not our enemies; they are our representatives. All we are asking of them is to please leave no action they could take untaken, in particular those that look like they could, and are likely to, make us legally complicit, whether we are ever followed up for that or not. As Irish people, we can lead. We do not always have to follow.

I echo what my comrades have said here. It is hard to continue watching what is happening and the mainstream media are not covering a lot. I do not think a lot of the people are aware of what is going on. This ceasefire has been detrimental in terms of people's awareness, in that it is only a ceasefire by name, not by action.

I think I have said plenty. To reiterate, the global movement to Gaza and the people of Ireland are clear in what we are asking for. We are asking the Government to take meaningful action. In taking meaningful action, it is to do what we cannot to impact Israel. It might not change everything but it can start something. As Ms Clancy said, we can lead and we should be leading, based on our past. One of the big reasons we are also asking to do this is so that the people of Ireland can stop putting their own lives at such risk. Another land convoy and a flotilla will be happening in the coming months. I guarantee the Comhchathaoirleach that thousands of people from Ireland are going to apply to go on this. People are putting their lives at risk in Ireland every day in relation to how they are acting for Palestine. They are putting their sovereignty at risk when they are being arrested and charged with crimes for trying to stop a genocide. People are going on the flotillas to try to stop a genocide because we do not believe our Government is taking as much action as it should.

I would like to comment on the fact that relying on purely diplomatic channels has resulted in a people and their land nearly being erased. That is the current situation. Palestine no longer appears on Google Maps. Israel appears. There is a very near brink of extinction of a people and a culture. That is not something that we can objectively watch without taking meaningful action. The jurisprudence of the International Court of Justice has dictated and determined that in various orders and advisory opinions that the settlements are unlawful, the occupation is unlawful, the blockade is unlawful and that four out of five of the acts required to constitute a genocide are present and have been present between 8 October 2023 and 31 July 2025. That is more than enough to categorically have a departure from diplomatic channels of negotiation with what can only be described as a rogue state and mandates a far stronger, more concrete approach, including boycott, divest and sanction.

We are veering into a dangerous territory internationally where the rule of law is being affronted. A mockery is being made of the rule of law because it is not being applied equally on the international scene and it is not being applied equally to certain groups of people, including Palestinians. As a human rights defender and as a lawyer, I am gravely concerned about the situation we are in internationally now, where the rule of law can so flagrantly and blatantly be abused and misapplied and there be zero consequences for the actors that abuse it.

I have two short things to say. I was asked earlier about trauma. One of my mechanisms to deal with it is to hide it and squash it down inside. It was only when something was mentioned here that I remembered when we were in the jail that you could hear the dogs barking at the Palestinians, wherever they were in this big prison. That still haunts me. It sits with me at night time and then I get emotional.

It was mentioned earlier on what tangible things we can do. Somebody somewhere signs contracts with Teva. Somebody somewhere signs contracts with Chequepoint. Without big fanfare, these things can be closed down when contracts are due for renewal. Israel has an old saying, "As long as people are talking, they are not doing". That is what it relies on. You will go to whatever meetings you go to and you will be talking to people. Israelis do not care. You are only talking, nothing is actually happening.

For those who were on the Global Sumud Flotilla, in years to come our children and grandchildren can look at us and say we did the right thing. We are on the right side of history. As it stands, the majority of people in power around the world are not on the right side of history. They are saying nice things and there are great soundbites but in terms of actions they are doing nothing. It is words not deeds for many of these people. It is just not happening. We will be back next year. We will have been kidnapped again one more time. Hopefully, nobody gets injured or killed. I do not see anything changing unless at a senior political level and global political level people change. It is deeds not words. They need to do things, not just talk about it.

One of the reasons I think we were enthusiastic as two committees to host this was at the initiative of Senator Chris Andrews and others. It was enthusiastically supported by all the members of both committees. It has been a privilege to co-chair it. It is important to have a record of these things into the future. We hope that we have assisted in a small part in ensuring that there is a record kept of this.

The question-and-answer session is now complete. I sincerely thank Mr. Mac Dubhghlais, Ms Clancy, Ms Brosnan, Ms Moynihan and Ms Schwarz for their attendance today and for their insightful and powerful contributions. What happened with the flotilla in international waters undoubtedly raises further and significant questions around the adherence to international law by Israel.

Indeed, many legal experts have suggested that the arrest of persons in international waters may be a serious breach of international law and I have made a commitment that we will follow up on some of the issues our witnesses have raised. Today's meeting also highlights the ongoing and dire humanitarian situation in Gaza. Of course, both committees will continue to follow and scrutinise the Irish and EU responses to this catastrophe, and today's engagement gives us further insight into the challenges posed by the ongoing conflict.

Finally, but not in any way least, I wish to acknowledge and commend the bravery of all who participated, including our witnesses here today, and Senator Andrews, who is a member of the Joint Committee on European Union Affairs. I thank the witnesses again and I look forward to further engagement in the future.

debateSection.summary: The joint committees adjourned at 5 p.m. sine die.
